question: I was standing there, and it was like the outside of me and the inside of me didn't match, you know? And then I looked around the room and it hit me. I saw my whole life. Where I was gonna live, what type of car I'd drive, who my neighbors would be. I saw it all and I didn't want it. Not that life. There's something out there for me, Dad. Something different. Something free form, you know? Something for me, and college just isn't it.
answer: That's too bad. You would have been the first one in the family.

question: I know.
answer: Alright. You want me to get your old job back? Because I could, you know, I could put in that word.

question: No, Dad. I don't want to...I mean, I just don't want...
answer: What are you going to do?

question: I'm going to California.
answer: I don't know about you, but I think we're gonna like it here.

question: California was like nothing I'd ever experienced. The people were liberated and independent and full of new ideas. They used words like "right on," "groovy," and "solid." The women are all beautiful and seemed to share the same occupation.
answer: Hey, wake up. Come on, you two lovebirds. Hurry, I want to show you something. Figured it out.

question: Figured what out?
answer: You know how we were wondering what we were going to do for money? Being how we don't want to get jobs and whatnot? Well, check this out.

question: Tuna, oh my. Enchante, George. Barbie, he's yummy. He looks like a Ken doll. Oooh, Ken and Barbie. It's perfect. Alright, girls, give me five minutes. Everyone, shoo! You, too, Barbie. I want to talk to the boys alone. What can I do for you guys?
answer: We want some grass.

question: I know what you want. But, first of all, are you cops?
answer: No.

question: Because if you are, you have to tell me. If not, it's entrapment.
answer: We're not cops. We're from Massachusettes. I mean, does he look like a cop?

question: I guess not. Okay. You know, you're very lucky you're friends of Barbie's. If you weren't, I'd never talk to you.
answer: What the fuck is that?

question: We'll take it. This is it for me.
answer: What is?

question: Just everything. You. California. The beach. This spot right here. I feel like I belong here, you know? It just feels right.
answer: You happy, baby?

question: Yeah. I am. I was standing there, and it was like the outside of me and the inside of me didn't match, you know? And then I looked around the room and it hit me. I saw my whole life. Where I was gonna live, what type of car I'd drive, who my neighbors would be. I saw it all and I didn't want it. Not that life. There's something out there for me, Dad. Something different. Something free form, you know? Something for me, and college just isn't it.
answer: That's too bad. You would have been the first one in the family.

question: I know.
answer: Alright. You want me to get your old job back? Because I could, you know, I could put in that word.

question: No, Dad. I don't want to...I mean, I just don't want...
answer: What are you going to do?

question: I'm going to California.
answer: I don't know about you, but I think we're gonna like it here.

question: California was like nothing I'd ever experienced. The people were liberated and independent and full of new ideas. They used words like "right on," "groovy," and "solid." The women are all beautiful and seemed to share the same occupation.
answer: Hey, wake up. Come on, you two lovebirds. Hurry, I want to show you something. Figured it out.

question: Figured what out?
answer: You know how we were wondering what we were going to do for money? Being how we don't want to get jobs and whatnot? Well, check this out.

question: Tuna, oh my. Enchante, George. Barbie, he's yummy. He looks like a Ken doll. Oooh, Ken and Barbie. It's perfect. Alright, girls, give me five minutes. Everyone, shoo! You, too, Barbie. I want to talk to the boys alone. What can I do for you guys?
answer: We want some grass.

question: I know what you want. But, first of all, are you cops?
answer: No.

question: Because if you are, you have to tell me. If not, it's entrapment.
answer: We're not cops. We're from Massachusettes. I mean, does he look like a cop?

question: I guess not. Okay. You know, you're very lucky you're friends of Barbie's. If you weren't, I'd never talk to you.
answer: What the fuck is that?

question: We'll take it. This is it for me.
answer: What is?

question: Just everything. You. California. The beach. This spot right here. I feel like I belong here, you know? It just feels right.
answer: You happy, baby?

question: Holy shit, Dulli. What the hell are you doing here?
answer: Well, I'll tell you. I was walking down the beach, minding my business, when who did I see but this fucking guy. I didn't know you guys were living in California.

question: Yeah, but what are you doing out here?
answer: I'm on vacation. On my way back to school.

question: This calls for a joint. You want to do the honors?
answer: No, man. I'm too fucked up.

question: Fuck yeah. I never seen nothing like it. I'm fucking wasted.
answer: Right on.

question: G-d, I'm stoned. I'm stoned. I'm really...
answer: Stoned?

question: I wish there was shit like this back home.
answer: Yeah?

question: I'm telling you, Derek, it will sell.
answer: I don't know...

question: Here's the best part. We can charge five-hundred a pound.
answer: Come on, George, no one is going to pay that.

question: It's already been negotiated. It's done. The money is there waiting.
answer: Goodness.

question: Goodness is right. If you do the math, that's over thirty grand a week profit. I want you to be my partner on this, Derek. Fifty-fifty. That's fifteen thousand a week for you, my friend. In your pocket, free and clear.
answer: And I only deal with you?

question: Ramon tells me you are looking for some mota.
answer: Yes, I am.

question: For instance, something like this?
answer: Very nice. I'll take it.

question: Ha ha ha. You are funny. Really, how much will you be needing?
answer: All of it. As much as you've got. A couples thousand pounds. I'll be back in a week with a plane.

question: Listen, Americano, it is very nice to meet you, but maybe we are going too fast. You take a little and then come back.
answer: I don't need a little. I need a lot.

question: Marijuana is illegal in my country, and I believe in yours, as well. We must be careful.
answer: What if I brought you, let's say, fifty thousand dollars? Would that eliminate some of your concerns?

question: Yes. Of course. But, I'm talking about that ring. It's something else. Let me tell you.
answer: George has exquisite taste.

question: What is that, two carats? That's got to be two carats.
answer: I don't know.

question: Oh, shut up, Fred. Shut your big fat mouth. You don't buy it all at once. It's called layaway.
answer: Layaway shmayaway.

question: That's right. Layaway. Something you wouldn't know anything about, you cheapskate.
answer: Who's the cheapskate?

question: Thanks. I'll be okay.
answer: You wanna split?

question: Yeah, I don't feel so well.
answer: Okay, guys, we're gonna leave. Let's get the check. Are you sure you're okay? You're pale.

question: I feel like shit. Me and my frigging nosebleeds.
answer: I'm taking you to the doctor when we get home, and I don't want to hear any arguments.

question: Would you be bummed out if I didn't go to Chicago with you?
answer: No, not at all. Sure. You're right. You fly home and get some rest.

question: Nice first impression. A nose bleed in front of your parents.
answer: Oh my G-d, how embarrassing were they? I wanted to shoot myself.

question: Oh, they weren't that bad. I mean, they were kind of cute.
answer: Promise me that we'll never be like them. I don't want to wind up like that.

question: Relax, baby. We're going to wind up like us.
answer: I had a little problem in Chicago. Something about trying to sell a truckload of dope to an undercover officer. So I applied the three rules of the game under if and when arrested. Rule one Rule two Your honor, I'd like to say a few words to the court. In all honesty, I don't feel like what I've done is a crime and I think it's illogical and irresponsible for you to sentence me to prison. None of the real criminals of the world ever end up behind bars. I mean, when you think about it, what did I really do? Cross an imaginary line with a bunch of plants? You say that I'm an outlaw, you say that I'm a thief, but where's the Christmas dinner for the people on relief?

question: Surprise.
answer: Baby, you didn't have to come.

question: What, and miss all the fun? C'mon, not a chance. So, what's the verdict?
answer: Lawyer says he can plead it down to five years. I'll serve two.

question: Two years. George, I can't wait that long.
answer: What? You're not going to wait for me?

question: George, I went to the doctor. I don't have two years.
answer: Which brings me to rule number three Time is such a funny thing. I look at where I am now, and in here, time inches along. So slow, it hardly seems like it moves. But back then, time went fast. It went too fast. Hi, Mom. Surprised to see me?

question: Which brings me to rule number three Time is such a funny thing. I look at where I am now, and in here, time inches along. So slow, it hardly seems like it moves. But back then, time went fast. It went too fast. Hi, Mom. Surprised to see me?
answer: Take your boots off. You're tan.

question: Mexico.
answer: Yeah. We heard all about it. I want you to know I'm deeply sorry about your girlfriend.

question: Barbara.
answer: Yes, Barbara. She was very pretty.

question: Thank you. Have you been getting the money I sent you?
answer: You mean the drug money? Yes, I got it. G-d, son.

question: Okay, Mom. It's okay. Where's Dad? May the wind always be at your back and the sun always upon your face...
answer: ...and the winds of destiny carry you aloft... You alright?

question: Just low.
answer: You loved her, didn't you? You really loved her.

question: Yeah, Dad. I really did. What am I gonna do?
answer: Tough spot.

question: You mad at me?
answer: Not mad.

question: Yeah, you are. I can tell by the way you look at me.
answer: I just don't know what you're thinking. I don't understand your choices. You know, the police are looking for you.

question: I know. I'm great at what I do, Dad. I mean, I'm really great.
answer: Let me tell you something, son. You would have been great at anything. Where are you going?

question: If you don't mind me asking, what is the reason you are in this place?
answer: What?

question: Your offense? Why are you here?
answer: I don't want to talk about it.

question: Intriguing. I see. Would you like to know my crime?
answer: Not really, no.

question: No?
answer: I don't like a lot of conversation, Diego.

question: Me, too. Too much blah, blah, blah, blah is no good. But we are roommates, okay? And we must talk to each other. I am arrested for stealing cars. For the grand theft auto. Okay? So, now it is your turn. Now you will tell me, okay? You will tell me why you are here? Oh, come on, George. If we are to be friends, we must trust each other.
answer: Murder.

question: Ah, yes. The murder.
answer: What do you got there, Diego?

question: Nothing. Just a little project.
answer: What kind of project?

question: Never mind. Not for you to worry.
answer: I thought you said we were roommates. That we should talk about everything.

question: You have your intrigues. I have mine. This is a happy day for me, George. Nine months from today, I will be in Medellin sipping champagne. In nine months, I am free. How much time do you have?
answer: Twenty-six months.

question: Twenty-six months? For murder? I must be your lawyer.
answer: I've got to get out of here, Diego.

question: Only two ways I know to leave here early. One is to escape.
answer: What's the other one? Alright, let's open our books. Alright. You're right. I want to get out of this shithole as fast as I can. And I don't want to do this any more than you do. But for me to walk early, some of you have to graduate. You, forget about it. You're hopeless, go to sleep. But the rest of you could get diplomas and get jobs when you're on the outside. We can learn some criminal shit, too. Alright, I'll make you a deal. What if half the time, we learn about George Washington, and the other half, I'll teach you how to smuggle drugs? I was arrested in Chicago with six hundred and sixty pounds of grass. I think that qualifies me. Flew it in from Mexico on a single engine Cessna. Now, do we have a deal or not? Alright, the first thing you need to know about smuggling drugs is that it's easy. The DEA are a bunch of losers. They couldn't find their dicks in a whorehouse. They don't know what the fuck they're doing...

question: George? Hey, George? I listen to what you say to the class today about the smuggling. You are a magico, ah? I never believed you were a murderer. I knew. I knew you are a magico. I have seen it in you. It's in your spirit.
answer: I'm tired, Diego. Go to bed.

question: You like to make the boundaries disappear. It's not only the money, is it, George? The adventure is part of the victory. It's the thrill, ah?
answer: Good night.

question: In my country, I am a magico. A man with a dream. A man on the rise. To take nothing and make it something, okay? I have failed my dream, but I will accomplish. That is why I am in your country. Yes, I lose my freedom. But they do not take my dream. Do you have a dream, George?
answer: I would if I could get some sleep.

question: Yes, you have a dream. And maybe you accomplish your dream. But yet you failed. Why?
answer: Because I got caught.

question: No, my brother.
answer: Because they caught me?

question: You failed because you had the wrong dream. George? What do you know about cocaine?
answer: I don't know, Diego. I've got a good thing going already. Everybody smokes pot. It's easy. Cocaine is a rich man's drug. It's too expensive.

question: No, no. That is where you are wrong. For us, it is cheap. In Medellin, we buy for six-thousand dollars a kilo. IN Miami, we sell for sixty.
answer: That's over fifty-thousand dollars profit per kilo.

question: And that's wholesale. Cut it a few times and retail, you're looking at two, three-hundred thousand.
answer: Oh my G-d.

question: Yes. And a kilo of coca is smaller than a kilo of your precious marijuana. Everything is the same, George, except instead of thousands, you are making millions.
answer: Jesus Christ. Jesus fucking Christ.

question: Now do you see what I am saying?
answer: Getting it here is no problem. Trust me. I'll fly it in myself if I have to. What about supply? How much can we get?

question: Don't worry. We will talk of everything. We have the time. You arrive here with a Bachelor of Marijuana, but you will leave with a Doctorate of Cocaine. What type of planes do you have?
answer: Four passenger, single engine Cessna.

question: How many kilos can we fit in these planes?
answer: I don't know. A hundred, hundred and fifty. How many miles is it from Colombia to Miami?

question: Fifteen hundred. We'll have to stop somewhere to refuel.
answer: We'll refuel in the Bahamas. I know someone there.

question: Great. I love the Bahamas.
answer: Diego Delgado, please?

question: Allo?
answer: Diego? It's George.

question: George, hallo! Today is the day, ah? Are you out?
answer: Yeah, I'm out.

question: Congratulations, brother. I've been waiting for you.
answer: How are we doing?

question: Perfect, George. Perfect. Everything is fine down here. Everything is all set up.
answer: Do we need a plane? How does this work? When do I see you?

question: Slow down, George. Slow down. You need to come down here, everybody meets everybody. Ho ho ho. Ha ha ha. We do one for good faith and then we talk about airplanes.
answer: I can't go anywhere, Diego. I'm on parole. I can't leave the state.

question: But you must. It's the only way.
answer: I just got released five minutes ago.

question: George, are we gonna do this or not?
answer: Good to see you, Diego.

question: Yes. Look around you. The sun. The water. The women. It's better than Danbury, no? Come on. I have some friends I would like you to meet. Fifteen kilos. Seven and a half in each suitcase. You receive a hundred thousand dollars upon delivery.
answer: Okay.

question: Hmm. I see. Will there be clothes in the suitcase?
answer: What? Yeah, sure.

question: Whose cloths? Your clothes?
answer: My clothes, your clothes. What does it matter?

question: I would like to know the contents. Every detail is important.
answer: What are we doing here, Diego? This guy's a clown. He's talking about clothes.

question: I demand to know everything. I do not trust six-hundred thousand dollars of coca to someone I don't know.
answer: It's a lousy fifteen kilos. I piss fifteen kilos.

question: The coca is my responsibility!
answer: You're a fucking amateur!

question: When you're carrying drugs across the border, the idea is to remain calm. The way I do it is to think of something pleasant, a fun party, a moment of triumph. A sexual encounter. I actually project myself to that place. Anything to keep your mind off the fact that you're going to jail for a very long time if they find the fifteen kilos of cocaine in your suitcases.
answer: On vacation?

question: Yes.
answer: On vacation for only one day?

question: My brother's wedding. Imagine that, huh?
answer: Open your bags, please. Whose clothes are these?

question: Mine.
answer: And this?

question: What can I tell you? Different strokes.
answer: Alright, go ahead.

question: We make the pick-up, refuel once more in the Bahamas, and fly back on Sunday with the mom and pop traffic.
answer: Why are you speaking?

question: Excuse me?
answer: You. Your responsibility is over. You do not fly. You are not a pilot. You are not a distributor. You introduced us to Mr. Stevens and the use of his airplane. That is all. You make a percentage. A generous one. And you're lucky to get that.

question: I see. How much?
answer: Padrino will pay ten-thousand per kilo. For everyone. For you, and you, and you. There is no negotiation. Three-million dollars. That is all.

question: Do you have pictures of your kids?
answer: What?

question: I'll need to see them. Also need their names and the names of their schools. We are trusting you with ninety million dollars worth of coca, Mr. Stevens. Without your children, there is no deal.
answer: Fine. So if that's all, I'll be leaving now.

question: George. George, come in here. What's the matter, George?
answer: What's the matter? We're moving three hundred fucking kilos and we're making dogshit.

question: A million dollars for our first run is not bad, George.
answer: It is bad. It's chump change. We might as well be hauling suitcases across the border. We're getting screwed.

question: I know.
answer: And what happens when these guys stop paying? Sooner or later, these guys are going to cut us out. Then where are we?

question: That's my George, always thinking. This is only part of the business, George. A very small part. Don't worry, there is so much more to do. Which reminds me, I need a favor from you. I must go to Colombia.
answer: What is it, George? Because I have to get home. I've got a parole officer waiting for me.

question: I need you to go to Miami.
answer: I'm George. Friend of Diego's?

question: I'm George. Friend of Diego's?
answer: QUIET! Callate! Where's Diego?

question: I don't know. He sent me. I'm George.
answer: Oh, I see. George. Well, that explains everything. Open your mouth, George. Now, you listen to me. Are you hearing me? You see this? I've been holding this shit for him for three weeks. You tell Diego I don't appreciate it. You tell him I want my money by Friday. Can you do that?

question: George.
answer: Jesus Christ, Diego, where are you? It's been eleven days and these guys want their fucking money.

question: Bad news, George. I'm in Colombia.
answer: Well, you better get here fast. I'm sitting on... Hi, Mom. I'm sitting on fifty fucking keys. Get your ass up here.

question: Not bad for a weekend's work, huh?
answer: Greetings, Mr. George.

question: Where do you guys want to count?
answer: On the plane.

question: What plane? We going someplace? Where we headed? You have your money. It's all there. What the fuck is going on?
answer: George, good to see you, my brother.

question: What the fuck is going on? When did you get out of jail?
answer: Pablo used his influence. Now, George, watch what you say. Everybody hears everything. A lot of things get said and done that, well, let's just say this isn't America. Life is cheap here, you know? No offense, but you know what I'm saying?

question: Yeah. Keep my mouth shut and let you do the talking.
answer: Right. Now who is the person in California? The connection?

question: Just a friend.
answer: Who? I need to know. Ah, never mind. We'll talk about it later.

question: Yeah. You do the talking.
answer: There must be some kind of mistake. It's alright, George. You go.

question: So, this is the man who takes fifty kilos and makes them disappear in one day?
answer: Actually, it was three.

question: The man who gives us the airplanes. The man from America. The mafia. Chicago. Boom boom. Hollywood. You are going to open for us the gates of Hollywood, George?
answer: It would be my pleasure.

question: Good. Very good. Welcome, my friend. Welcome to my country. The man in the garden. He was full of courage.
answer: Un sapo?

question: Un rata - no good. But he could have run, fled the country. Gone to the policia. But then his wife, his children, his parents, his friends, many people would die.
answer: Yes.

question: But, never mind. I am thinking we can do much together. This problem with Diego, the stolen car, the jail, is very silly business. To release him from the carcel, it causes me much inconvenience. The fifty kilos could have been a big problem. And I don't like problems.
answer: With all respect, Padrino. Diego is my partner. I do not do business without him.

question: I like you, George. You are loyal. That is good. That is rare. Maybe crazy. Yes. I can tell already. You are like me. I look at you and I see myself. It's in the eyes, no, George?
answer: Yes, it is.

question: So, you are wanting to sell the cocaine for me in your country, George?
answer: Yes, sir. As much as you can give me.

question: As much as I can give you? Ha ha. Very good. I like that. Come, George. Let us drive. We have much to talk about. I like to come up here. To make the decisions. To be one with nature.
answer: It's beautiful.

question: People tell me that I am crazy. That my business will never work in your country. What do you think, George?
answer: What do I think? I don't want my answer to be influenced by what I want, so I'm going to have to say I don't know.

question: Yes. I do not know, either. What do you want, George?
answer: I want money.

question: Yes. Money. Which is what, George?
answer: Freedom.

question: Power?
answer: Yeah, maybe.

question: Family.
answer: Sure.

question: Beautiful girls?
answer: Keep them coming.

question: Keep them coming? Ah, yes. Ha ha. You are right. But money.
answer: Money.

question: And Diego?
answer: Diego is my brother.

question: Three million. I counted it twice.
answer: It's two-point-five, George. I am sure.

question: I'm calling it three.
answer: We're half a million off.

question: Fuck it. I'm not counting it again.
answer: Weight it. If it's sixty pounds, it's three. If it's fifty, it's two-point five.

question: I don't give a shit. Close enough. Where do I put this!?
answer: Try the back bedroom.

question: There's no room.
answer: Try the closet.

question: We've got to do something about this. Are you comfortable with this?
answer: George, we've got sixty-one million dollars. It's either here or someplace else. We've got to put it somewhere. Unless you want to launder it.

question: And keep only forty-percent? No thanks.
answer: Then relax. It's a federal bank. Guaranteed by the government. And Senor Noriega has very lenient banking principles. No questions. No problems. All the pesados keep their money here. Even El Padrino. What do you worry? Everyone knows we are with Escobar. Who is going to fuck with us?

question: I love it. I give you thirty-million dollars and you give me this little book.
answer: I'm married, George. Me. I can't believe it. Can you believe I'm married, George?

question: You're a lucky man, Diego.
answer: I love you, my brother, do you know that?

question: I love you too, man. I'll be right back, Diego.
answer: Great, baby, great!

question: Hello.
answer: Hello.

question: Do I know you?
answer: I don't think so.

question: Why are you smiling?
answer: Why are you smiling?

question: I don't know. My name is George.
answer: I know who you are, El Americano. Mister George.

question: I think Padroni is happy with the current situation. Will you please excuse me?
answer: You better know what you're doing, George. You're playing with fire.

question: I like fire.
answer: I do. I need a fucking drink.

question: Jesus Christ.
answer: Oh, don't be such a fucking hypocrite. I quit smoking, didn't I?

question: Look at this credenza. If you don't mind me asking, how much is something like that? It's got to cost a fortune.
answer: It's a family heirloom.

question: I've seen those in magazines. They're not cheap.
answer: Mirtha comes from a very wealthy family.

question: So, business is going good. I've got this import/export thing going on in Miami that's been very profitable. With my investments...
answer: Don't bullshit me, George. I don't see you very much, I don't want to waste the time. You come from my body, remember? You're my baby boy. The same kid who would jump off a mountain if someone told him he couldn't do it. You haven't changed much. I know the things you do. Not everything. But I get the picture and I don't care. I don't like it. It's not what I would have chosen for you, but it's your life. It doesn't have anything to do with me. You're like your mother. You love money.

question: Dad.
answer: No, it's good. You have a family. It's good if it makes you happy. It's nice to have nice things. Are you happy, son?

question: Yeah, Dad. I'm happy right now.
answer: Three years. How long have we been in business? Three years. Does she get to meet your connection? Was she good enough?

question: Shut up, Diego. They're going to be here any minute. I'm trying to concentrate.
answer: I'm very angry with you, George. Very angry. You don't take me to California, but you take your bitch wife? A woman? I understand you love her, but it was you and me who started this. You and me.

question: What do you need my connection for, Diego? What are you going to do with it?
answer: What do I do with it? Nothing. It's for peace of mind. It's for the principle.

question: Jesus fucking Christ, Diego. I ain't telling you. It's just business. Now, shut up. You're driving me crazy.
answer: I'm driving you crazy? No. You're driving me crazy. We had a dream. What happened to our dream?

question: No no no... no problema, amigo. El dinero esta todo aqui. Lleves las "llaves" y mas tarde lo contaremos. Okay? No problem.
answer: You embarrassed me, George. You make me look very bad.

question: Nothing. Todo esta bien.
answer: Everything is not alright. I bring you in, and you slap my fucking face!

question: This is not the time, Diego.
answer: You fucked me in front of my whole family!

question: Fuck you...I didn't fuck you. Esta todo aqui, amigo...take the keys. Take 'em and go.
answer: Sientese ye no se meta en lo que no le importa.

question: Take it easy! Everything's okay!
answer: Que es lo que quieren de me, hijueputas campesinos?

question: Take the fucking keys! Estoy bien, okay? Everything is alright. There's no problem. Okay? This never happened. No one has to know anything about this. Diego, I want you to calmly tell them where the fucking coke is. Do it now.
answer: Es un Ford blanco junto a una pick-up.

question: No problem, gentlemen. Goodbye. Derek Foreal.
answer: What?

question: He's not here, George.
answer: Yeah, well where is he? And who is this Norman K. guy? That's all anyone is talking about. Norman K. Norman K. Do I know him?

question: Norman Cay is not a person. He is an island, George. In the Bahamas. From what they say, it is free and it's Diego's new home.
answer: What?

question: Let us walk. From what I understand, Diego has bought a hundred and sixty acres, a marina, a hotel, and an airstrip.
answer: Motherfucker works fast.

question: The word is that soon he is to be king of the middle empire. He is doing multiple runs right now and using the island as a jump-off point.
answer: He what?

question: Hey, Arch, you think the judge will let us get a cocktail after this is all over? Thanks, Arch. I'm George Jung. Spelled J-U-N-G. Yes, I do. Yes, he's sitting right there at the end of the table. Shortly after I arrived at Danbury Federal Correctional Institute I related to Diego that the crime I was in for was smuggling marijuana. Diego told me he had high level connections in Colombia and they needed to find someone to help them transport cocaine into America... The first run was fifteen kilos, which we smuggled into Logan Airport in hard shelled suitcases. We wrapped the cocaine in kitchen cabinet paper, and duct tape, that way if there were any dogs in customs... I introduced Diego to a pilot named Jack Stevens, who helped us fly 300 kilos of cocaine per week into the United States via twin-engine Cessnas. Jack would fly into North Carolina, we'd meet him there and drive it down to different distribution points... I never met Pablo Escobar. Diego Delgado was my only connection to cocaine from Colombia... Diego convinced me to keep most of my money in a Panamanian bank. Diego had a close relationship with Manuel Noriega. In exchange for allowing us to keep our money there, we paid him a percentage. There was an 85% chance that if you snorted cocaine between 1977-1984, it was ours. Initially with my LA connections, we invented the marketplace. In 1977, there was no other real competition. The first year we made about 100 million dollars between us. It was an expensive operation. Eventually we built up to three different pilots doing multiple runs per week, connections on both coasts, everything was running smooth. We were like a corporation... he was very anti-government. He talked about revolution, forming his own country or island, he was looking for power as well as money. I was just looking for money. He disliked the United States, thought it was a police state. He hoped that by flooding the country with cocaine, it would disrupt the political system and tear down the morality of the country. Well, yes, Derek Foreal was my connection, I met him back in 1968 when I first moved to Manhattan Beach. It was Foreal's marijuana connections that kicked off our cocaine market. Yes, it was my idea to bring the kilos to Los Angeles. When Diego finally got Derek Foreal's name from me, it was only a matter of months before he'd cut me out. I'm not sure how my relationship with my daughter and ex-wife have anything to do with this trial. I mean we're here to talk about Diego Delgado, aren't we?
